entities.name: harry potter
entities.description: The main character of the story, a young wizard who is about to start at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. He is described as being on his way to a wizards' school and has a ticket with platform 9 and three-quarters written on it.

entities.name: hagrid
entities.description: A wizard who gave Harry the ticket for the train. He is not physically present in this scene but his actions have an impact on the story.

entities.name: uncle vernon
entities.description: Harry's uncle, a Muggle (non-magical person) who is skeptical of magic and wizards. He is described as being dismissive and disbelieving of Harry's story.

entities.name: aunt
entities.description: Harry's aunt, a Muggle who shares Uncle Vernon's skepticism and disbelief in magic.

entities.name: kings cross
entities.description: A train station in London where Harry will be taking the train to Hogwarts. It is mentioned as a place that Harry's aunt and uncle are already planning to visit.

entities.name: platform nine and three-quarters
entities.description: The platform at King's Cross station where Harry will be taking the train to Hogwarts. It is written on his ticket and mentioned as a place that does not exist according to Uncle Vernon.

entities.name: london
entities.description: A city in England where Harry's aunt and uncle are already planning to visit. They will be taking Harry with them to King's Cross station.

relationships.description: Harry is going to take the train from platform 9 and three-quarters, as written on his ticket. This is mentioned in the text: 'I just take the train from platform nine and three-quarters at eleven o'clock,' he read.
Harry will be taking the train to Hogwarts from King's Cross station. This is mentioned in the text: 'We're going up to London tomorrow anyway, or I wouldn't bother.'
Harry will be taking the train to Hogwarts from King's Cross station in London. This is mentioned in the text: 'We're going up to London tomorrow anyway, or I wouldn't bother.'
Harry's uncle Vernon is related to him and is skeptical of his story. This is mentioned in the text: 'Don't talk rubbish,' said Uncle Vernon, 'there is no platform nine and three-quarters.'
Harry's aunt is related to him and shares her husband's skepticism of his story. This is mentioned in the text: 'His aunt and uncle stared.'
